content:
Note: Corrections or comments are welcome.

A directed graph is a functor G:X→Set,\mathcal{G}: X\to\mathsf{Set},G:X→Set, where XXX is a category with two objects X0,X1X^0,X^1X0,X1 and two morphisms s,t:X1→X0.s,t:X^1\to X^0.s,t:X1→X0. The set G0=G(X0)\mathcal{G}^0 = \mathcal{G}(X^0)G0=G(X0) is the set of vertices and the set G1=G(X1)\mathcal{G}^1 = \mathcal{G}(X^1)G1=G(X1) is the set of directed edges. If ϵ∈G1\epsilon\in\mathcal{G}^1ϵ∈G1, it is a directed edge from the source node s(ϵ)s(\epsilon)s(ϵ) to the target node t(ϵ).t(\epsilon).t(ϵ).

The category DiGraph\mathsf{DiGraph}DiGraph is the functor category [X,Set].[X,\mathsf{Set}].[X,Set].

Composing a graph G\mathcal{G}G with a free functor FVect:Set→Vect\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Vect}}: \mathsf{Set}\to\mathsf{Vect}FVect​:Set→Vect gives a span

V0←sV1→tV0V^0\overset{s}{\leftarrow} V^1\overset{t}{\rightarrow} V^0V0←sV1→tV0

where V0=FVect(G0)V^0 = \mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Vect}}(\mathcal{G}^0)V0=FVect​(G0) is a vector space of nodes and V1=FVect(G1)V^1 = \mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Vect}}(\mathcal{G}^1)V1=FVect​(G1) is a vector space of directed edges.

An algebra is a monoid in Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect so we can consider a free functor

FAlg:Vect→Alg,\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Alg}}: \mathsf{Vect}\to\mathsf{Alg},FAlg​:Vect→Alg,

where Alg=Mon(Vect)\mathsf{Alg} = \mathsf{Mon(Vect)}Alg=Mon(Vect) so that the composite

FAlg∘FVect∘G:X→Alg\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Alg}}\circ\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Vect}}\circ\mathcal{G}: X\to\mathsf{Alg}FAlg​∘FVect​∘G:X→Alg

is a span of algebras

A0←sA1→tA0,A^0\overset{s}{\leftarrow} A^1\overset{t}{\rightarrow} A^0,A0←sA1→tA0,

where A0=FAlg(V0)A^0 = \mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Alg}}(V^0)A0=FAlg​(V0) is an algebra of nodes and A1=FAlg(V1)A^1=\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Alg}}(V^1)A1=FAlg​(V1) is an algebra of directed edges.

(I'm shaky on this one.)

We can consider another free functor

FSpan1:Alg→Span1(Alg)\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Span}_1}: \mathsf{Alg}\to\mathsf{Span_1(Alg)}FSpan1​​:Alg→Span1​(Alg)

so that the composite

FSpan1∘FAlg∘FVect∘G:X→Span1(Alg)\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Span_1}}\circ\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Alg}}\circ\mathcal{F}_{\mathsf{Vect}}\circ\mathcal{G}: X\to\mathsf{Span_1(Alg)}FSpan1​​∘FAlg​∘FVect​∘G:X→Span1​(Alg)

consists of two objects A0,A1A^0,A^1A0,A1 and morphisms consists of composable spans

A0←sA1→tA0.A^0\overset{s}{\leftarrow} A^1\overset{t}{\rightarrow} A^0.A0←sA1→tA0.
Whats up with the last functor? It seems it does nothing!
Yeah. I had something else written there and edited it and now I am confused myself. That is why I prefaced it "I am shaky on this one" :) I am not sure about that last step.

Since I started this journey, things have changed a little bit (thank goodness!).

For one, I am no longer using the traditional definition of a directed graph as a functor X→SetX\to\mathsf{Set}X→Set as described above. Instead, now I think of a directed graph as an endomorphism in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set), which is captured nicely via a functor
{}
G:N→Span(Set)G:\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}G:N→Span(Set)
{}
with
{}
G(∙)=V,G(1)=E:V→V.G(\bullet) = V,\quad G(1) = E:V\to V.G(∙)=V,G(1)=E:V→V.
{}
Given a span of sets
{}
V←E→VV\leftarrow E\rightarrow VV←E→V
{}
we can construct a cospan of algebras
{}
KV←KE→KVK^V\leftarrow K^E\rightarrow K^VKV←KE→KV
{}
or (I think) a span of vector spaces
{}
K[V]←K[E]→K[V].K[V]\leftarrow K[E]\rightarrow K[V].K[V]←K[E]→K[V].
{}
Both can be thought of as functors, i.e.
{}
K−:Set→AlgK,V↦KVK^-: \mathsf{Set\to Alg}_K,\quad V\mapsto K^VK−:Set→AlgK​,V↦KV
{}
and
{}
K[−]:Set→VectK,V↦K[V].K[-]: \mathsf{Set\to Vect}_K,\quad V\mapsto K[V].K[−]:Set→VectK​,V↦K[V].
{}
Since I'm trying to do this incrementally, it probably makes sense to think about K[V]K[V]K[V] a bit since KVK^VKV is dual to K[V]K[V]K[V] :thinking:
{}
So I think I'll spend some time thinking about
{}
N→Span(Set)→Span(VectK).\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)\to Span(Vect}_K).N→Span(Set)→Span(VectK​).
